I want T.J McConnell back on the 6ers. As a benchplayer/coach transition player. Go the Walton route but actually be good at coaching lol.  No cost too high for the heart and hustle king.

Like most right-thinking Americans, I like those players who are gym rats. Who play the game with smarts and grit. Coaches' sons. Make up for lack of athleticism with pure skill and intellect. Never say die guys, the ones who are first in the gym and last out, who always put up extra shots. Guys whose pants don't sag and whose shirts are always tucked in. The kind you want to bring home to mom for Sunday dinner. I think you know what I'm getting at.   1. Kyle Korver   2. Peyton Pritchard   3. Duncan Robinson   4. T.J. McConnell   5. Grab bag: any Plumlee or Zeller

column1: **TEAM LUNCH PAIL**  Fueled by the hype from his 10 steal game, the NBA greenlights a lunch pail team that consists primarily of T.J. McConnell clones. Sure enough, the gym can't open SOON ENOUGH for these plucky vets. According to reports, they're each in there every morning by 3 A.M.  Unfortunately, the team had a stroke of bad luck when their request for a Plumlee led them to Marshall Plumlee, arguably the worst of the bunch (albeit plucky and hard working.) Unlike brother Mason, Marshall doesn't possess enough skill or speed to compete with the top centers in the league.  As a result, opponents take advantage of team Lunch Pail's limitations inside, scoring often in the paint. McConnell + McConnell + McConnell + McConnell proves to be scrappy enough to stay in most games and even beat a few tanking teams, but ultimately the talent deficit leads to a disappointing 12-70 record.

Steals =/= defense.   In fact, you can gamble for steals and be an absolutely atrocious overall defender.  Iverson wasn't a bad defender, but he was slightly negative in defensive real plus-minus for his career. (I know DRPM is not the only defensive stat, but I am using it as an example)  Look at it this way.  Who is currently second in the NBA in steals per game?  Why it's T.J. McConnell, whose defense is currently rated as 88th (out of 91) among point guards in the NBA.   [http://www.espn.com/nba/statistics/rpm/\_/sort/DRPM/position/1](http://www.espn.com/nba/statistics/rpm/_/sort/DRPM/position/1)  (you will find him on page three, at the bottom)
“2 steals in 3mins? Amateur.” -T.J. McConnell

Lol the Pacers with the highest RAPTOR this year was T.J. McConnell, and the player with the highest last year was Justin Holiday, the year before, Thad Young.  How are your bench guys and secondary players your best players year after year?  Does this mean that your core is.........shit?  How is anyone expecting these rosters to even make the playoffs, much less go deep in the postseason?

Question from NBA.com’s GM Survey 2021-22:  Which active player will make the best head coach someday?  1. Chris Paul, Phoenix – 34%  2. Rajon Rondo, Lakers – 14%  3. T.J. McConnell, Indiana – 10%  4. Mike Conley Utah – 7% Udonis Haslem, Miami – 7% Garrett Temple, New Orleans – 7%  > Also receiving votes: Harrison Barnes, Sacramento; Malcolm Brogdon, Indiana; Draymond Green, Golden State; Joe Ingles, Utah; LeBron James, Lakers; Patty Mills, Brooklyn

Both are high level defenders, and great passers and primary ball handlers.  T.J. does throw up 3s on occasion, but rarely, generally preferring to be a playmaker.  He has more steals than a 1920s gangster.  When I was looking through the Pacers roster for potential Simmons trades I certainly passed right over McConnell.  I'd be neutral on a straight up trade, probably slightly preferring to keep McConnell but still think that we'd probably lose more games with T.J. than Simmons on the roster.  It's not even close, but I mean, it's kind of close.
